sub_topic: Finding the area under a curve using integration
message_1: Find the exact area bounded by the curve y = x^2 and the x-axis over the interval [1, 4] using integration.
message_2:
To find the exact area bounded by the curve y = x^2 and the x-axis over the interval [1, 4], we will use integration. The area can be found by evaluating the definite integral of the function y = x^2 with respect to x from 1 to 4.

The integral of x^2 with respect to x is (1/3)x^3. Now we need to evaluate this antiderivative at the bounds 1 and 4:

A = âˆ«(x^2)dx from 1 to 4 = (1/3)x^3 | from 1 to 4

Now, we will substitute the bounds:

A = ((1/3)(4)^3) - ((1/3)(1)^3)
A = ((1/3)(64)) - ((1/3)(1))
A = (64/3) - (1/3)
A = 63/3

So, the exact area bounded by the curve y = x^2 and the x-axis over the interval [1, 4] is 63/3 square units.
